comment._content: Could he be the son of the President of Guatemala en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manuel_Estrada_Cabrera

comment.author: 23103743@N05
35014516@N03
comment._content: pennylrichards: Thanks for the correction on the original caption.  swanq: Thanks for linking us to his probable identity.  We'll include the new information next time we update our description.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: There is an obituary in the 11/10/12 New York Times for Francisco Estrada Cabrera, eldest son of the Guatemalan president, dead in Guatemala City at age 21. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9B05E4D9133CE6... However, this may be an error. Other accounts say that Diego was his eldest son, Francisco the next of three sons. Diego had been schooled in Berkeley, California. One account has Diego fatally ill with "consumption" in 1910, racing home from Europe to die in Guatemala.

comment.author: 35014516@N03
comment._content: artolog:  Thanks for the additional information and the link--useful when we make our update.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: I have found a more authoritative source, a biography of Manuel Estrada Cabrera. Francisco (Paco or Paquito) Estrada, aka Francisco Estrada Ocampo, committed suicide in the presidential palace on November 8, 1912. However, this picture is obviously much earler than 1913. He was the eldest (legitimate) son at the time of his death, as his older brother Diego had died in 1910, either of TB or as a suicide motivated by his illness. www.archive.org/details/eccepericles00arguat The memoir quoted by Swanq, above, tells the story of Francisco's death as related to the author by his father, called to the presidential palace that night.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: @artolog:  Thanks.  I had meant to find time to gather sources to make the same points.  The whole story reminds me of a Shakespearean version of a classical tragedy -- e.g., Coriolanus.
